page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY IN EPSOM
page.content: {The name Epsom or Ebbesham derives from the Anglo-Saxon name "Ebbi" and "Ham" meaning village: so Ebbi's village became Ebbesham, Epsham, Epsom. {The borough's coat of arms}was designed by Revd. E.E. Dorling and was accepted in 1937. The green and white in the arms represents the verdure and the chalk of the Downs; the golden horses Epsom's association with horse racing; and the blue wavy lines represent the springs in Ewell. {The Wells}were opened in 1618 and led to Epsom's fame as a spa town. However in 1707 John Livingstone's rival wells led to the decline of Epsom as a spa.{Epsom developed as an {important residential area}and many mansions were built, such as Waterloo, Ashley, and Richmond houses, as well as the Durdans, Lord Rosebery's home.
